current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Shrinking regulations have helped expand revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cannabis equipment and accessory stores have been given a wider berth in which to operate in recent years. Twenty-four states have legalized recreational cannabis use, 15 of which have done so since 2019.   This has helped foment revenue growth. It's easier for cannabis equipment and accessory stores to operate in locales where recreational cannabis is legal, as the market is larger.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A positive macroeconomic environment has supported growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In an effort to prevent a recession, the Federal Reserve imposed several interest rate hikes over 2023. Despite that, the macroeconomic environment has remained positive, particularly for consumers, in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. Consumer spending and per capita disposable income have been on the rise, though stimulus payments complicate disposable income movements. This has provided consumers with an opportunity to spend money on cannabis equipment and accessories.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A reversal of fortune could prove disastrous
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Decriminalization and legalization of cannabis has been a popular trend since Colorado and Washington legalized recreational cannabis products in 2012. In the years since, a significant number of states have either decriminalized or legalized recreational products. This has enabled cannabis equipment and accessory stores to operate more easily. There's momentum at the federal level to change cannabis' status as a Schedule I drug under the Controlled Substances Act, which would boost these stores even more.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Saturation is forecast to cut into profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Cannabis equipment and accessory stores have undergone a large increase in saturation in recent years, as the number of establishments has grown nearly 50.0% since 2019. This trend is forecast to continue has legalization grows and cannabis products become more socially accepted in the coming years. This has given consumers more options to purchase cannabis equipment and accessories, which has boosted price-based competition as stores try to attract customers. Lower prices are forecast to take a chunk out of profit.

key_trends: In the context of the coronavirus outbreak, this industry only exhibited small declines while other consumer-facing industries endured stiff revenue
There is a higher concentration of industry establishments where marijuana and hemp production is legal recreationally and medically
Rising acceptance and legalization of medical and recreational marijuana and cannabis has pushed up demand for industry products
A reversal of fortune could prove disastrous
Saturation is forecast to cut into profit
Over the next five years, growth in the number of states with recreational marijuana is expected to drive an increase in the number of industry locations

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PURCHASES ARE BY FAR THE LARGEST COST CATEGORY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: At more than half of revenue, purchases are a significant cost category for cannabis equipment and accessory stores. This trend follows the broader retail sector, which must purchase products to sell to consumers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a

FAQs.question: Some jurisdictions don't permit consumers to grow their own products, which keeps this share of revenue relatively low.
FAQs.answer: This refers to the revenue share from consumers growing their own products, which is relatively low in some jurisdictions that don't permit it.

FAQs.question: Lights also are often less expensive than other growing equipment.
FAQs.answer: This suggests that lighting equipment is often less expensive compared to other equipment needed for growing products.

FAQs.question: High barriers to entry mean that new companies struggle to enter an industry, while low barriers mean it is easy for new companies to enter an industry.
FAQs.answer: This is the definition of barriers to entry, explaining that high barriers make it difficult for new companies to enter an industry, while low barriers make it easy.

FAQs.question: Compares the amount of money spent on capital (plant, machinery and equipment) with that spent on labor. IBISWorld uses the ratio of depreciation to wages as a proxy for capital intensity. High capital intensity is more than $0.333 of capital to $1 of labor; medium is $0.125 to $0.333 of capital to $1 of labor; low is less than $0.125 of capital for every $1 of labor.
FAQs.answer: This defines capital intensity and how it is measured, providing thresholds for high, medium and low capital intensity based on the ratio of capital expenditure to labor costs.

FAQs.question: The dollar figures in the Key Statistics table, including forecasts, are adjusted for inflation using the current year (i.e. year published) as the base year. This removes the impact of changes in the purchasing power of the dollar, leaving only the "real" growth or decline in industry metrics.
FAQs.answer: This explains that the financial data and forecasts are adjusted for inflation to the current year, in order to show the real growth or decline in industry metrics, removing the impact of changes in the purchasing power of the dollar.
